title: Tycoons To Back Wealth Firm Amid Legal Row
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Oct 16, 2015, 01:44 BST - UK Markets open in 6 hrs 16 mins Tycoons To Back Wealth Firm Amid Legal Row By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 3 hours ago View Photo 

A quartet of wealthy City figures is lining up to back a new wealth management venture whose founder is embroiled in a bitter legal battle with the founder of the Phones 4U mobile phone retailer. 
Sky News understands that Nathalie Dauriac-Stoebe, whose new firm is expected to launch within months, has secured backing from Vin Murria, a partner at Elderstreet Investments, Dominic Silvester, the chief executive of Nasdaq (NasdaqGS: NDAQ - news ) -listed insurance company Enstar; and Nicholas Packer, another Enstar executive. 
Ms Dauriac-Stoebe's new firm, which is to be called Hay Hill, will also count the former Conservative Party treasurer Lord Fink among its investors, as Sky News reported last month . 
The launch of the firm, which is said to be planning to open its doors with £300m in assets under management, will attract attention in the City because of a spectacular falling-out between Ms Dauriac-Stoebe and John Caudwell, a former backer of her previous firm, Signia Wealth. 
Ms Dauriac-Stoebe and Signia are now suing each other following her sudden exit from the firm nine months ago. 
Lord Fink's backing for Ms Dauriac-Stoebe comes several months after Ed Miliband, the then Labour leader, accused David Cameron of surrounding himself with "dodgy donors" after Mr Fink had said that "everyone does tax avoidance at some level". 
Senior (Other OTC: SNIRF - news ) figures in the City were outraged by Mr Miliband's reference to Lord Fink, who insisted that he had eschewed more aggressive tax avoidance measures that would have saved him and his family vast sums of money. 
Lord Fink has donated substantial sums to a number of charities and has worked for a range of philanthropic causes after amassing a big fortune from roles, including running Man Group (LSE: EMG.L - news ) , the quoted hedge fund. 
A former partner at Coutts, Ms Dauriac-Stoebe founded Signia Wealth in 2010, building it into a firm which claimed to manage more than £2bn of clients' assets. 
She (Munich: SOQ.MU - news ) is often labelled one of the rising stars of the City and named in lists of the financial sector's leading women executives. 
Her plans to launch Hay Hill come amid a shake-up in the regulation of the wealth management sector following the implementation of a framework called the Retail Distribution Review, which is designed to improve advice and transparency around client fees. 
Meanwhile, the private banking arms of lenders such as Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) and Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) , which owns Coutts, have been experiencing a significant period of upheaval amid broader restructuring of their parent companies. 
A spokesman for Ms Dauriac-Stoebe declined to comment.
